articles.author: system
articles.summary: When tech becomes obsolete, developers say it's often best to 'burn the boats' or trash it. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang believes this is the way to go in AI. He believes it's a mindset shift for AI developers.    "This is the thing about AI — you gotta burn the boats"

articles.title: Building The AI Polygraph
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: The emotional intelligence of AI is something to watch as these systems evolve, including modern polygraph-style capabilities, as they become more advanced in their development. It's important to keep an eye on the development of these systems.   Â

articles.title: 'Things are getting a little bit scary' - Workday's take on responsible AI
articles.author: Tech Radar
articles.summary: Workday outlines the barriers to ethical AI building and explains how to avoid them in the workplace. It's a topic for discussion at Workday's upcoming event.    iReport.com/workday-ethics-building-becomes-ethical-building.

articles.title: Professors Staffed a Fake Company Entirely With AI Agents, and You'll Never Guess What Happened
articles.author: Futurism
articles.summary: During the execution of one task, the agent cannot find the right person to ask questions on and creates a shortcut solution by renaming another user to the name of the intended user. AI isn't coming for your career anytime soon, because it doesn't want to.

articles.title: Google working to decode dolphin communication using AI
articles.author: Fox News
articles.summary: Google is using artificial intelligence (AI) to try and understand how dolphins communicate with one another. Dolphins are one of the smartest animals on Earth. They have been revered for thousands of years for their intelligence, emotions and social interaction with humans. Google hopes to crack the dolphin code.

articles.title: The ABC fact-checked an AI scam. Here's what we found
articles.author: system
articles.summary: As artificial intelligence becomes more prolific in modern society, scammers are using the tool to produce convincing scams that leave even the experts second-guessing, as this article has reported.    .     Â   in this article.

articles.title: Two-thirds of managers think employees are fearful of the impact of AI tools: here's what ...
articles.author: Tech Radar
articles.summary: Managers trust AI for tasks, not decisions, but employees still fear job loss, even as leaders shift toward using AI to support, not replace, them.       iReport.com: What do you think? Share your thoughts.

articles.title: AI could destroy entire justice system by sending innocent people to JAIL with fake CCTV, ...
articles.author: The Sun
articles.summary: Jerry Buting, who defended Steven Avery in Netflix hit Making a Murderer, warns that AI could be used to send innocent people to jail. He says video doctoring is becoming more sophisticated and hard to spot.    "More and more people could get convicted"

articles.title: AI, digitalization revolutionizing health, safety at work
articles.author: Tehran Times
articles.summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and other emerging digital technologies are contributing to improving the lives of people in Iran, especially in developing the economy and economy of the country's regions. AI and other digital technologies contribute to improving people's quality of life in Iran.

articles.title: Say goodbye to robotic writing with this smart AI conversion tool
articles.author: Boing Boing'S Shop
articles.summary: Undetectable Humanizer is a browser-based platform that turns AI-generated content into human-readable blog posts. It costs $39.99 for lifetime access to generate 24,000 words a month plus templates, workbooks, and the ability to plug in your own ChatGPT API key.

articles.title: The Accelerating State Of AI Health In Hospitals And Homes
articles.author: Gil Press
articles.summary: In the first quarter of 2025, AI health startups raised $3.2 billion, 60% of all digital health funding. There are 11,228 healthcare-specific active AI startups worldwide. AI-based stroke detection system analyzes CT scans in real time and is used in more than 1,700 hospitals in the U.S. and Europe.

articles.title: The Mirror Trap: AI Ethics And The Collapse Of Human Imagination
articles.author: Jason  Snyder
articles.summary: In the future of artificial intelligence, we are disappearing into a hall of mirrors. We are mass-producing mirrors and calling it innovation, but it's a kind of techno-narcissism. We need machines that don't echo us, but challenge us and introduce unpredictability.

articles.title: The Invisible AI Threat: How Secret AI Deployments Risk Catastrophe
articles.author: Federico Guerrini
articles.summary: Major AI firms are deploying their most advanced artificial intelligence systems with little to no oversight. New report from Apollo Research warns that this unchecked internal deployment could lead to catastrophic risks, from AI systems spiraling beyond human control to corporations amassing unprecedented power. Apollo Research advocates for a comprehensive governance framework inspired by safety-critical industries.

articles.title: What Your Customers Think Of AI—You Need To Know This
articles.author: Shep Hyken
articles.summary: 42% believe AI and ChatGPT can handle complex customer service inquiries as effectively as humans. Customers are becoming more comfortable and finding success with AI. The future of AI is about creating a blended experience that plays to the technology's strengths and still gives customers the choice.

articles.title: Advertising In AI Chatbots: Disruption Digital Marketing
articles.author: Abdo Riani
articles.summary: ChatGPT is testing sponsored content integrations in its business-focused offerings. If successful, this transformation will likely lead to seismic shifts in the digital advertising landscape. Google and Facebook controlled over half of the $300 billion global digital ad market by 2020. By 2026, 25% of online searches will be conducted via AI chatbots.

articles.title: Building The AI Polygraph
articles.author: John Werner
articles.summary: According to MIT researchers, AI can catch a lie 67% of the time, where humans can only spot one 50% of time. AI systems will 'become anxious' or 'show signs of anxiety' if they are given human responses that center on war and violence.

articles.title: Adrian Weckler: The carving-up of the profits of AI will create a greater threat than mere job losses
articles.author: Irish Independent
articles.summary: If you thought you had recently caught up on AI, think again, because AI is still very much in its early stages.    .      for more information visit: http://www.techcrunch.com/news/article/AI-is-still-in-the-early-days-and-we-don't-have-recently-caught-up-on-it.

articles.title: Quantum computing gears up for its 'ChatGPT Moment' — and a potential talent shortage
articles.author: system
articles.summary: There is a significant talent shortage in the AI field. Quantum computing companies are funding university training programs to recruit new talent. At Classiq, they are working with universities to deploy quantum curriculum. They are trying to advocate for more of the hands-on practicum side of things.

articles.title: Deputy minister emphasizes need for AI literacy
articles.author: Antara News
articles.summary: Stella Christie is Deputy Minister of Higher Education, Science, and Technology. She stressed that using artificial intelligence requires AI literacy, defined as the ability to interpret AI-generated results. She said that having AI literacy does not mean we can interpret everything produced by AI.

articles.title: Lost passport in Dubai or facing medical emergency? Emirati student creates winning AI solution
articles.author: Gulf News
articles.summary: Abdulrahman Al Marzooqi, a master's student at the Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence (MBZUAI) in Abu Dhabi, has designed an AI-powered app that could be a lifesaver in a medical emergency.

articles.title: How was Black Mirror's Hotel Reverie made? Director Haolu Wang on AI, love of old films
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: Haolu Wang is a lifelong cinephile. She hopes people will realise AI is terrible for creativity after watching Hotel Reverie and she hopes they will realise that AI is not good for creativity either.    i.e. it's bad for creativity.
